Elite Operator Toolkit

Regulation Engine: Tactical Assignment

System Ready

System Briefing: The Regulation Engine

Elite performance is defined by the ability to regulate your internal operating system under pressure. While physical skill sets the floor, your mental fitness sets the ceiling. This assignment uses four Manual Overrides to ensure you stay in your Ideal Performance State (IPS).

Dashboard Logic: Read then Regulate

Somatic Indicators (Body)

Cold hands, butterflies, muscle tension, sweating.

Cognitive Indicators (Mind)

Negative self-talk, doubt, inability to concentrate.

Station 01: The Stress Loop Reset

The Pivot Point

Breathing is your manual override switch. It intercepts the Stress Process Loop at the moment a demand is perceived as a "threat." The goal is to identify a specific time you can execute this trigger and how the breath anchor will help you stay present in the moment.

Warning:

Unchecked loop acceleration leads to performance crash.

Identify a specific time you can execute this trigger.

How will this breath anchor help you stay present in the moment?

Station 02: Arousal Volume Control

The Inverted-U

Performance peaks at moderate arousal. You must 'down-regulate' to discharge tension or 'up-regulate' to wake the nervous system.

PMR (Progressive Muscle Relaxation) is a technique where you systematically tense and then relax specific muscle groups to release physical tension.

Describe your routine to discharge somatic tension.

Up-Regulation involves using physical actions or environmental triggers to increase heart rate and alertness when energy is too low.

Triggers used to discharge apathy and enter the zone.

Station 03: The Focus Filter

Attentional Narrowing

Under high stress, your peripheral vision and mental focus shrink‚Äîoften called "Tunnel Vision." You lose the big picture. Cue words act as "Decoder Keys" that force the system to lock back onto task-relevant targets.

The Goal:

Shift from internal worry (Emotion) to external cues (Action).

Create a 1-2 word key specifically to FIX sloppy mechanics or technical errors.

Create a 1-2 word key specifically to FIX low energy or effort when drive is fading.

Identify the exact moment panic sets in and which cue breaks the jam.

Station 04: Confidence Builder

Certainty Logic

Uncertainty generates anxiety; Certainty generates confidence. You cannot control the outcome (Winning), but you can control the process (Mechanics). By shifting your focus to what you control, you build a "High Confidence" state.

S.M.A.R.T. Definition

  • SPECIFIC: Clear and defined.
  • MEASURABLE: Can be tracked.
  • ACHIEVABLE: Realistic to your skill.
  • RELEVANT: Matters to your sport.
  • TIME-BOUND: Has a deadline.

This goal builds high confidence because it is entirely under your power.

Partial Control.

Low Control.

Welcome to the Values Blueprint. High performance is built on integrity‚Äîthe gap between your words and your actions. Turn your core beliefs into tactical behaviors.

What is a Value?

A belief that is most important to you. It helps you find your way when things are difficult. It is who you are at your best, serving as a filter for hard decisions.

In Alignment Behavior

Focus Master Blueprint

Phase 3: Concentration & Attention

System Ready

Step 00: Focus Mission Control

"Concentration is the master art because all other arts depend on it." This blueprint helps you build a "Fortress of Focus" to move from Self 1 (the critical ego) to Self 2 (the instinctive doer).

Data Safety Protocol

This system auto-saves to your browser. However, to prevent data loss (if you clear cache or switch computers), you must use the SAVE BACKUP FILE button above to download your progress. Use LOAD BACKUP to restore it later.

The Spotlight

Your attention is a beam of light. Most performers fail because their spotlight is too broad (distractions) or pointed at the past/future. We need it Narrow & External.

Cues & Anchors

A Cue is a word that triggers a behavior. An Anchor is a physical sensation (like the seams of a ball) that keeps your mind in the "Now."

Self 1 vs Self 2

Self 1 is the voice in your head that judges and yells. Self 2 is your body's natural ability. To win, we must Quiet Self 1 and Trust Self 2.

Quiet Eye

The final fixation on your target before moving. Elite performers have a stable "Quiet Eye" that allows their brain to process motor plans without interference.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.content:
It was a relatively normal day at the pharmaceutical firm where Ginny Stevens worked as a midlevel executive. She knew there‚Äôd be a product presentation to a conference room full of corporate vice presidents today, but she was one of several attendees with no formal role in the actual presentation, so she was her usual calm and relaxed self. All that changed as she left her office and headed to the meeting. Her boss caught up to her just a few strides away from the conference room door and told her that she would be giving the presentation herself. What followed was a moment of utter panic.

Ginny described it to me this way: ‚ÄúI stopped in midstride and my head did such a fast 180 to look back at my boss that I almost hurt my neck. I take pride in being a good employee, so I really couldn‚Äôt say no. But inside my mind was screaming, ‚ÄòWhat!?! Are you kidding me? You want me to do a presentation to a room full of VPs with no forewarning and no preparation?!!‚Äô We kept walking toward the conference room and the doors seemed to grow before my eyes, getting bigger and bigger until it seemed like I was entering some huge cathedral where a council of elders was waiting to pass judgment on me. Even though I knew the product pretty well, I had no idea how I was going to pull this off. I just about lost it when the doors opened and I could see those VPs sitting inside waiting for me.‚Äù

Luckily for Ginny, the VPs took it easy on her and the presentation turned into a pleasant, collaborative conversation. But it might not have gone that way, and Ginny‚Äôs moment of panic was so upsetting that she knew she had to do something about it. ‚ÄúI hear that you help athletes with their confidence,‚Äù she said to me, ‚Äúbut I sure need it, too. And so does my entire work team. Can you help me? I don‚Äôt ever want to feel that way again.‚Äù

Ginny‚Äôs story is one I have heard a thousand times: a sudden change of circumstance or situation sends someone into a tailspin of self-doubt. The heart starts pounding, the thoughts start racing, and even everyday perceptions of time, space, and surroundings shift uncomfortably. One moment you are walking to a run-of-the-mill event, and the next moment you are staggering toward what seems like your own execution.

But it doesn‚Äôt have to be that way. You can armor yourself against any unexpected turn of events and also against all the known and expected difficulties of life by building for yourself a personal mental fortress, a guaranteed foolproof bank that holds your personal confidence account.

How do you build that bank? You start with some strong foundations, and naturally, because this is a mental bank account, your foundations are mental too. There are four mental pillars that we begin with, four factors that affect all human performance. Once you accept them, you‚Äôll see the pursuit of excellence a lot more clearly, and you‚Äôll have the peace of mind that will help you win the First Victory.

The First Victory is a concept I use in my work with athletes. Before any athlete (or anyone) can win the ‚ÄúSecond Victory‚Äù‚Äîthe externally recognizable achievement, such as a championship title or a promotion or a successful social interaction‚Äîhe or she must first win the First Victory, the internal victory over their own doubts, fears, and worries. Put simply, the First Victory is the moment when the question ‚ÄúCan I do this?‚Äù is answered in the affirmative.

When you win the First Victory, you don‚Äôt necessarily feel euphoric or invincible. You just feel like you can handle what is in front of you. You feel solid. You can breathe and focus and get down to the business of doing what you know you can do.

The problem is that most of us do not reliably win that First Victory. Instead, we often lose it. We lose it before we even get the chance to compete or perform. We lose it in the minutes and hours leading up to the event. We lose it because our minds are not trained to support us.

So the first thing to do is to accept certain realities of being human. We can‚Äôt make them go away. We can deny them, fight them, resent them, and try to pretend they don‚Äôt exist, or we can accept them and learn to use them.

That‚Äôs what this chapter is about: accepting what you cannot change.

The four pillars that I‚Äôm about to describe are not ‚Äútips‚Äù or ‚Äútricks.‚Äù They are not optional. They are the concrete realities of being a human being trying to do something difficult in the presence of other human beings.

We can choose to ignore these concrete realities of our human existence, or we can choose to acknowledge them and work with them. The former path leads to stagnation and mediocrity, and the latter path to growth and success. The choice is yours. Let‚Äôs explore the four pillars of a kick-ass confident attitude.

sections.heading: Pillar #1: The Mind-Body Connection Is Real. Use It or Be Used by It.
sections.content:
The term mind-body connection entered the public vocabulary during the late 1960s and early 1970s, a period of considerable social and ideological change. In earlier years, it was generally understood in Western rational scientific thought that the mind and the body were entirely separate and distinct; your thoughts and emotions were the domains of priests and poets, while your body, obeying the physical laws of chemistry and physics, was the domain of mechanistically trained medical doctors. So it really didn‚Äôt matter what or how you thought‚Äîyour body, the instrument through which you played your sport or performed at your job, didn‚Äôt care. That started to change during the late ‚Äô60s and early ‚Äô70s, largely due to new research in the fields of neurology and endocrinology.

In short, the mind-body connection is the principle that the thoughts and emotions you experience affect the physical state of your body and thus affect your physical performance. Your thoughts and emotions can make your performance better or worse.

This connection is constant. It‚Äôs not something that turns on and off. It‚Äôs happening right now as you read these words.

The mind-body connection works through the nervous system, and it works through the hormones that the nervous system helps regulate. It works through changes in muscle tension, breathing patterns, blood flow, digestion, and sensory perception.

When your mind is filled with fear, doubt, and worry, your body responds in predictable ways. Your muscles tense up. Your breathing becomes shallow. Your vision narrows. Your body floods with stress hormones. You become physically less capable of performing your best.

The mind-body connection is not ‚Äúmystical‚Äù or ‚Äúspiritual.‚Äù It is a physical reality. Your thoughts have consequences.

Think of it this way: your thoughts and emotions produce a physical state, and that physical state in turn produces more thoughts and emotions. This is a cycle.

When your emotional state is driven by fear, doubt, and worry, it produces a physical state of tightness and tension. That tightness and tension then creates more fear, doubt, and worry. The cycle feeds itself.

I call this the sewer cycle.

You can visualize it this way:

Conversely, if your emotional state is driven by a flood of constructive thoughts (notice I did not say ‚Äúpositive‚Äù thoughts), it produces a rather different and vastly more effective physical state. Instead of feeling tense, you feel energized; your vision opens up instead of closing in; there are natural pain-reducing chemicals released in the brain. All these changes make your best possible performance far more likely, as pictured below:

[FIGURE: Diagram illustrating the sewer cycle and the success cycle (mind-body feedback loops)]

Three key points about these cycles are important to winning the First Victory. First, we all find ourselves switching back and forth from the not-so-helpful sewer cycle to the more helpful success cycle many times a day and even many times an hour. No one, not the mentally toughest, most confident individual on the planet, is immune to the occasional trip around the sewer cycle. What matters, then, is (1) how often and how frequently you‚Äôre on which cycle and (2) which cycle you‚Äôre on when it‚Äôs time to perform. Take this simple two-question test right now. Answer honestly: What percentage of your conscious thoughts over a day, a week, a semester, a season, or a year are personally affirmative and emotionally supportive, and what percentage are personally disparaging and emotionally discouraging? And where do your thoughts tend to run when you are moments away from stepping into your personal performance arena? Do they move you toward the sewer or more toward the success cycle?

Second, you can‚Äôt stop the mind-body connection. It‚Äôs built into the human operating system. You can only decide whether it will work against you or for you.

Third, the First Victory is not won in some distant future moment, when you have finally achieved some mythical ‚Äúperfect confidence.‚Äù The First Victory is won in the moment when you recognize the mind-body cycle you are currently on and deliberately choose to shift onto the more helpful cycle.

That shift is not a matter of willpower. It‚Äôs a matter of practiced thinking. It‚Äôs a matter of having habits of thought that reliably lead you to constructive emotions, which then lead to constructive physical states.

If you understand this pillar, you can stop being surprised by your own physical reactions to stress. You can stop thinking that the pounding heart and the tight chest mean that you are ‚Äúnot confident.‚Äù Instead, you can recognize them as predictable outputs of a nervous system that has been influenced by your thoughts.

And you can change those thoughts.

The mind-body connection is real. Use it or be used by it.

sections.heading: Pillar #2: Inevitable Human Imperfection. You Won‚Äôt Escape It, So You Might as Well Make Friends with It.
sections.content:
Here is the second pillar: you are going to mess up.

You‚Äôre going to make mistakes. You‚Äôre going to have bad days. You‚Äôre going to forget things you practiced. You‚Äôre going to make the wrong decision at the wrong time. You‚Äôre going to look foolish. You‚Äôre going to feel embarrassed. You‚Äôre going to feel regret.

And this will happen even if you are talented, even if you are prepared, even if you have trained hard, even if you care deeply.

This is not a pessimistic statement. It is a liberating statement.

Most people carry around a hidden assumption that if they are ‚Äúgood enough,‚Äù they will not make mistakes. They assume that mistakes are evidence that they are not good enough.

That assumption is wrong.

Mistakes are evidence that you are human.

The difference between people who become excellent and people who stay mediocre is not that the excellent people don‚Äôt make mistakes. The difference is how they respond to mistakes.

When you make a mistake, you can respond in one of two ways.

You can respond with shame.

Shame is the belief that a mistake means you are a flawed person. Shame turns an event into an identity. Shame says, ‚ÄúI messed up, therefore I am a mess.‚Äù Shame is self-attack.

Or you can respond with guilt.

Guilt is the belief that a mistake means you did something that needs correcting. Guilt turns an event into information. Guilt says, ‚ÄúI messed up, therefore I need to adjust.‚Äù Guilt is self-coaching.

Shame is destructive. Guilt is constructive.

Shame drains your mental bank account. Guilt can actually build it.

Here is why: when you respond to a mistake with shame, your mind fills with negative thoughts. Those thoughts trigger the mind-body connection. You tense up. You feel threatened. You become less capable of executing the skills you have. And the negative thoughts continue. The sewer cycle begins.

When you respond to a mistake with guilt, your mind stays engaged with the task. You stay oriented toward improvement. You stay oriented toward the future. You keep your emotional energy.

This is what I mean by making friends with inevitable human imperfection.

You need to accept that imperfection is part of the package. You can‚Äôt avoid it, so you might as well build a relationship with it.

Think about it: if you believe you must be perfect to succeed, then every mistake is catastrophic. Every mistake is proof you‚Äôre not ready. Every mistake becomes a reason to doubt yourself.

But if you accept imperfection as normal, then mistakes become expected. They become part of the process. They become feedback.

This doesn‚Äôt mean you excuse your mistakes. It means you respond to them like a professional.

Professionals evaluate mistakes and then move on.

They don‚Äôt keep replaying them.

They don‚Äôt keep punishing themselves.

They don‚Äôt create a negative identity out of a single event.

The most important skill here is the ability to ‚Äúforget‚Äù the imperfection once you‚Äôve extracted the lesson from it. That does not mean you deny the mistake. It means you don‚Äôt carry it forward emotionally.

If you find yourself replaying mistakes and insulting yourself for them, you are not ‚Äúbeing accountable.‚Äù You are draining your bank account.

It is always possible to say to yourself: ‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt good. Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôm going to do differently next time.‚Äù Then you commit to doing that next time, and you let the mistake go.

This is not soft. This is not coddling. This is how excellence is built.

If you want to win the First Victory consistently, you have to stop demanding perfection from yourself.

You have to accept that imperfection is inevitable.

You won‚Äôt escape it, so you might as well make friends with it.

sections.heading: Pillar #3: Your Helpful, But Mostly Misunderstood, Autonomic Nervous System. Fall in Love with Your Butterflies.
sections.content:
Now we arrive at the pillar that causes the most confusion and the most needless suffering: your autonomic nervous system.

The autonomic nervous system is the part of your nervous system that controls your automatic bodily functions: heart rate, breathing, blood flow, sweating, digestion, and more. It operates largely outside your conscious control.

And it is the system that produces the physical sensations we associate with anxiety: the pounding heart, the fluttering stomach, the sweaty palms, the tight chest.

Most people interpret these sensations as a sign that something is wrong.

They interpret them as a sign that they are ‚Äúnot confident.‚Äù

They interpret them as a sign that they are ‚Äúnot ready.‚Äù

They interpret them as a sign that they are about to fail.

That interpretation is the problem.

Those sensations are not evidence that you are weak.

They are evidence that your nervous system is doing its job.

Your autonomic nervous system has one primary mission: to help you survive.

When it detects that you are about to do something important, something uncertain, something that matters, it activates.

It releases energy.

It prepares you for action.

This activation is not your enemy. It is your ally.

The problem is that most people don‚Äôt know how to interpret the activation. They see it as a threat. That thought triggers the mind-body connection and pushes them onto the sewer cycle.

But if you understand the autonomic nervous system, you can interpret the activation differently.

You can interpret it as fuel.

You can interpret it as readiness.

You can interpret it as your body saying, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go.‚Äù

This is why I tell athletes to fall in love with their butterflies.

The butterflies are not a sign that you‚Äôre in trouble.

They‚Äôre a sign that you care.

They‚Äôre a sign that you‚Äôre alive.

They‚Äôre a sign that you‚Äôre about to do something challenging.

You can‚Äôt get rid of the butterflies, because they are produced by a system that exists to prepare you for challenge.

And you don‚Äôt want to get rid of them.

If you had no activation, you would be flat.

You would be under-energized.

You would be indifferent.

The goal is not to eliminate activation. The goal is to harness it.

The autonomic nervous system is intelligent. It learns.

It learns what you interpret as threatening.

It learns what you interpret as exciting.

It learns what you interpret as normal.

If you repeatedly interpret activation as a threat, it will keep activating in ways that feel threatening.

If you repeatedly interpret activation as fuel, it will still activate, but you will experience it as fuel.

This is why the best performers in the world are not ‚Äúcalm‚Äù in the sense of being emotionally flat.

They are energized.

They are activated.

They have butterflies.

They just don‚Äôt panic about them.

They understand the system.

They respect the system.

They don‚Äôt try to fight it.

They work with it.

When I work with athletes, we spend a lot of time training this reinterpretation.

We train them to recognize autonomic activation and label it as readiness.

We train them to smile when the fuel shows up.

We train them to say, ‚ÄúGood. This means I‚Äôm ready.‚Äù

And when they do that consistently, their nervous system becomes a reliable ally.

This pillar matters because if you misinterpret the autonomic nervous system, you will sabotage yourself right before performance.

You will take your own fuel and turn it into fear.

If you interpret it correctly, you will take your own fuel and turn it into focus.

Fall in love with your butterflies.

sections.heading: Pillar #4: The Inconsistent and Delayed Returns of Practice. Great Changes Are Happening That You Can‚Äôt See.
sections.content:
The final pillar is the one that breaks the spirit of most people before they ever get close to their potential: the inconsistent and delayed returns of practice.

Most people have a simple, childish expectation about practice:

If I practice, I should get better.

And not only should I get better, but I should get better quickly.

And not only should I get better quickly, but I should get better in a smooth, predictable, linear way.

That expectation is wrong.

Practice does make you better.

But the returns are delayed.

And they are inconsistent.

And they are often invisible while they are happening.

This is why practice is so mentally challenging.

You can work hard for days or weeks and feel like nothing is changing.

You can work hard and actually feel worse.

You can have a great practice and then a terrible one.

You can have a breakthrough and then regress.

You can feel like you‚Äôre going backward.

And then suddenly, one day, something clicks.

The nervous system is changing in ways you cannot consciously feel.

The body is adapting in ways you cannot consciously perceive.

Great changes are happening that you can‚Äôt see.

But because you can‚Äôt see them, many people conclude that practice is not working.

They lose faith.

They lose patience.

They drain their mental bank account.

They quit.

The people who become excellent are the people who stay in the game long enough for the invisible changes to become visible.

They understand that practice is not a vending machine.

You don‚Äôt put in effort and get out improvement immediately.

Practice is more like planting seeds.

You water the soil, you pull weeds, you tend the garden.

And for a long time, you see nothing.

But the roots are growing.

The system is changing.

And then, eventually, the plant emerges.

This is why consistency matters more than intensity.

Because the changes happen over time.

This is why patience matters more than excitement.

Because the returns are delayed.

This is why trust matters more than mood.

Because the returns are inconsistent.

You can‚Äôt base your commitment to practice on how you feel today.

You have to base it on a long-term understanding of how change happens.

If you accept this pillar, you can stop being surprised by the normal ups and downs of progress.

You can stop interpreting a bad day as evidence that you are failing.

You can stop interpreting a plateau as evidence that you are stuck.

You can stop interpreting a setback as evidence that you are doomed.

Instead, you can interpret these things as part of the process.

You can keep practicing.

You can keep depositing.

You can keep building.

And you can protect your mental bank account from the impatience that destroys so many people.

Great changes are happening that you can‚Äôt see.

Stay with it.

sections.heading: Selective Thinking and the Mental Filter
sections.content:
Back in the 1990s, before the coming of video streaming services like Netflix, a common family ritual was the weekly trip to the local video store. There Mom and/or Dad could find a drama or action movie, and the kids could find a G- or PG-rated movie of their choice. Being dutiful parents, my wife and I embarked on many such trips, bringing home such classics as First Wives Club, Wayne‚Äôs World, and Mrs. Doubtfire, (yes, I know I‚Äôm dating myself). We‚Äôd all huddle on the living room couch and crank up the now obsolete VCR machine. On one of these trips my two young daughters ran over to me after making their selection from the rack. ‚ÄúDaddy, can we get this one?‚Äù It was the recently released comedy Dumb and Dumber, starring Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels as two bumbling adults with the common sense and worldly experience of ten-year-olds. I remember not being impressed with my daughters‚Äô selection, but being the doting dad that I was, I relented and prepared myself for a very forgettable evening. I was getting pretty much what I expected (slapstick gags and scatological jokes) when there appeared on my TV a scene that I had to stop, rewind, and watch again. It‚Äôs the scene (maybe some of you have seen it) where Jim Carrey‚Äôs character, Lloyd, a gangly, homely, and altogether unsophisticated man, has finally tracked down the beautiful Mary (played by Carrey‚Äôs soon-to-be wife, Lauren Holly) and asks her if there is any way the two of them could ever end up together as a romantic couple. Not wanting to be rude, but utterly uninterested in Lloyd, Mary tries to let him down gently with a few noncommittal answers. Finally Lloyd insists that she give him a straight answer about what his chances are. ‚ÄúNot good,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúLike one out of a hundred?‚Äù Lloyd asks. ‚ÄúMore like one out of a million,‚Äù she answers, knowing that she has just broken the poor man‚Äôs heart. Upon hearing this pronouncement Lloyd at first swallows hard and bites his lip, disappointed that his quest for love seems hopeless. But after a moment‚Äôs reflection he smiles a huge, gap-toothed smile and proclaims, ‚ÄúSo you‚Äôre telling me there‚Äôs a chance!‚Äù before breaking into a howl of glee. He has determined that he actually has a chance at love after all. Not much of a chance, to be sure, but enough of a chance in his own mind to be a cause for celebration. First Victory won.

In that moment Lloyd exhibited the single most important mental skill anyone can have, and indeed must have, to build confidence in an indifferent and often uncaring world. He is thinking selectively‚Äîonly allowing into his mind thoughts and memories that create energy, optimism, and enthusiasm. He may only have one chance in a million, but he is completely focused on that one chance and consequently he feels on top of the world. Because of the ongoing mind-body connection presented in Chapter One, Lloyd‚Äôs optimistic feeling will keep him pressing on in his persistent pursuit of love.

Put differently, Lloyd displays a remarkably effective mental filter‚Äîa screen through which all his thoughts and experiences pass before they become part of his running total, before they can affect his mental bank account‚Äîeither building it up or bringing it down. This filter performs two functions in the service of that mental bank account. It allows the thoughts and memories that create energy, optimism, and enthusiasm to pass through and build the mental bank account up, but it prevents the thoughts and memories that create fear, doubt, and worry from getting in and drawing the bank account down. With a functioning mental filter, you could play in an afternoon softball game, get only one hit in four at bats, and spend the evening reliving and enjoying that one successful trip to the plate. Naturally, you might also want to sharpen up your batting stance and your swing with a little practice before your next game, but by hanging on to the memory of that one hit, rather than beating yourself up by reliving the three misses, you give the part of your nervous system that sees the ball and swings the bat an image of what you want more of, and thus you get that mind-body connection described in Chapter One working for you.

This is precisely how the best hitters in baseball have always thought. Hall of Famer Tony Gwynn exercised his mental filter by editing the video of each at bat after every game. Into one video file he would put his best at bat from the game, and into another file he would put his worst at bat from the game. Guess which file he would study? The best at bat file. This is not because Gwynn was deluding himself or avoiding the reality of his flaws. It is because he understood that you improve by giving your nervous system a clear picture of what you want to repeat.

Whatever your conscious mind tends to dwell on, your nervous system will tend to repeat.

If your conscious mind dwells on the failures, your nervous system gets a picture of failure.

If your conscious mind dwells on the success, your nervous system gets a picture of success.

Tony Gwynn knew that the mind-body connection works both ways, and he was deliberately using his mind to influence his body.

The question is: are you?

If you don‚Äôt have a filter, your mind becomes a junkyard.

Every failure becomes a permanent resident.

Every mistake becomes a defining event.

Every disappointment becomes a repeated movie.

And your mental bank account is constantly drained.

If you do have a filter, your mind becomes a bank.

You keep the valuable deposits.

You use the deposits to build optimism and enthusiasm.

You still learn from mistakes, but you don‚Äôt keep them as emotional baggage.

This is the core skill that will allow you to build your confidence account: selective thinking.

Selective thinking is not denial.

Selective thinking is not arrogance.

Selective thinking is not pretending you are better than you are.

Selective thinking is choosing which experiences and memories you keep emotionally alive.

You cannot control everything that happens to you.

But you can control what you do with what happens.

That is the beginning of mental strength.

Now let‚Äôs get practical.

The rest of this chapter will give you specific exercises to build your filter and deposit ‚Äúmoney‚Äù into your mental bank account by filtering your past for valuable deposits.

sections.heading: Exercise One: Your Top Ten
sections.content:
Think back to when you first started participating in your chosen field (from here on in I‚Äôll use this term, chosen field, to refer to whatever it is that matters most to you and whatever it is that you desire to excel in‚Äîyour chosen sport, profession, etc.). What did you enjoy about that activity? What made it cool, or fun, or interesting for you? It may be hard to put a finger on it but I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs a feeling, a rather special feeling, back there in your memory. Center yourself on that feeling and then start thinking about the best times you have ever had in that activity.

I want you to identify your Top Ten experiences in your chosen field, the ten best experiences you can recall‚Äîmoments of achievement, progress, victory, enjoyment, and satisfaction. These memories can be from any time in your life: last week, last year, ten years ago, or more.

This is not a list of your ten biggest external accomplishments. It is a list of your ten best internal experiences.

The moment when you finally ‚Äúgot‚Äù something.

The moment when you did something you didn‚Äôt think you could do.

The moment when you felt like you were ‚Äúin the zone.‚Äù

The moment when you felt proud.

The moment when you felt like this activity was yours.

Write them down.

Do not worry about writing them in perfect language. Just capture them.

And don‚Äôt be surprised if you find yourself smiling as you do this.

Those smiles are deposits.

If you are like most people, you may find that your mind initially resists this exercise.

You may find that you are more practiced at remembering failures than successes.

You may find that you have trained yourself to be ‚Äúrealistic‚Äù by focusing on what went wrong.

But this exercise is not about being unrealistic.

It‚Äôs about being accurate.

Your past is not only failures.

Your past includes successes.

Your past includes progress.

Your past includes moments of excellence.

Those are real.

And they matter.

This exercise is the first deliberate step in building your filter.

Once you have your Top Ten, read them.

Then read them again.

Then ask yourself a simple question: what do these memories have in common?

You will likely find that they reveal something important about you.

They reveal that you have already done hard things.

They reveal that you have already improved.

They reveal that you are not starting from zero.

They reveal that you are a bigger fish than you may have been telling yourself.

In my work with athletes, I often hear a version of the same complaint: ‚ÄúCoach, I‚Äôm just not confident.‚Äù When I ask them to tell me about their best performances and best experiences, they suddenly realize they have been undermining themselves by failing to keep their own deposits.

Here is an example of how this dialogue typically went:

PLAYER:
I just don‚Äôt feel confident.

ME:
Tell me about the best times you‚Äôve ever had in your sport.

PLAYER:
Well, I mean, I‚Äôve had some good days, but that‚Äôs in the past.

ME:
So you‚Äôre telling me you‚Äôve had good days.

PLAYER:
Yeah, but those don‚Äôt matter now.

ME:
Of course they matter. They matter because they prove you can do it.

PLAYER:
But all that‚Äôs in the past. I‚Äôm at a whole new level of competition now.

ME:
Yes. And that‚Äôs exactly why you need to remember just how big a fish you are.

PLAYER:
I figure by now I wouldn‚Äôt need to be nervous before competition.

ME:
That‚Äôs Pillar #3. You‚Äôre going to be nervous. The question is what you do with it.

PLAYER:
I never realized I was undermining myself by thinking that way!

How big a fish are you? Put together your My Top Ten list and I bet you‚Äôll be pleasantly surprised by the answer.

sections.heading: Exercise Two: Your Daily E-S-P
sections.content:
Now that you‚Äôve got your bank account started, the work of deliberately building it up and protecting it from losses really begins. The confidence that you want to feel six months from now when you take the MCAT or compete in that conference tournament is either built up day by day or allowed to diminish day by day. In fact, every day is a source of deposits, and you will find them if you choose to look for them.

This is where the Daily E-S-P comes in.

E-S-P stands for Effort, Success, and Progress.

Every day, you are doing things that require effort.

Every day, you are having some successes.

Every day, you are making some progress.

The problem is that most people let these deposits disappear.

They don‚Äôt acknowledge them.

They don‚Äôt record them.

They don‚Äôt let them build interest.

Instead, they live as if the only things that matter are the mistakes.

The Daily E-S-P is a simple practice.

At the end of each day, or at the end of each practice session, or at the end of each workday, you identify and write down:

1. One thing you did that required effort.
2. One thing you did that was a success.
3. One thing you did that represented progress.

These can be small.

In fact, they should often be small.

Because small deposits add up.

And because the whole point is to train your mind to notice what you are doing right.

Effort deposits matter because effort is the one thing you can always control.

Success deposits matter because success is evidence.

Progress deposits matter because progress is the story of improvement.

This exercise is not about ignoring problems.

You still fix problems.

You still learn.

But you stop letting the mind default to negativity.

A lot of people ask me, ‚ÄúHow can writing down these little things make any difference?‚Äù

My answer is simple: because of the mind-body connection and because of memory.

Your nervous system is influenced by the images your mind provides.

If you provide it with images of effort, success, and progress, you are literally training yourself to repeat those things.

And because these deposits are recorded, they begin to earn interest.

You begin to build a running total.

You begin to build evidence.

You begin to build trust.

There is also the mental management principle of ‚Äúlost opportunity.‚Äù How many opportunities to win a First Victory are you missing out on by not taking advantage of your daily experience? Without meaning to, you are likely contributing to your own stagnation by letting moments of effort, success, and progress go by unacknowledged.

This exercise is a direct attack on that lost opportunity.

It forces you to notice the deposits.

It forces you to keep them.

It forces you to become your own coach.

It is simple.

And it is powerful.

sections.heading: Exercise Three: The Immediate Progress Review, or IPR
sections.content:
This brings us to the last and potentially most powerful method of building your bank account by filtering memories from your past. Your account will grow fastest when you make the greatest number of deposits possible and give those deposits the maximum possible time to earn interest. That being the case, you can take advantage of the opportunities to reflect and filter in constructive memories during the course of a workday, or a practice session, or a workout, not just at the end of the day.

The Immediate Progress Review, or IPR, is exactly what it sounds like.

It is a quick, deliberate review of what you just did that went well.

It can take ten seconds.

It can take thirty seconds.

It can take a minute.

The key is that it is immediate.

Right after you do something well‚Äîright after you make a good decision, right after you execute a skill correctly, right after you make a small improvement‚Äîyou pause and you take it in.

You let the nervous system see it.

You let the brain record it.

You let the deposit land.

This is how you accelerate learning.

This is how you build confidence quickly.

Because you are not waiting until the end of the day to notice the deposits.

You are collecting them in real time.

In high-performance environments, this is incredibly relevant.

In sports, every successful rep is a deposit.

In academics, every solved problem is a deposit.

In medicine, each contact with a patient, each consult with a team member, each case completed, and each filed surgical report can all be filtered and can all serve as sources of energy, optimism, and enthusiasm.

These three exercises, the Top Ten list, the Daily E-S-P, and the Immediate Progress Review, are how you can make the most of your memories, both those from long ago and those from what happened just moments ago. None of them require much in the way of time, and let‚Äôs face it‚Äîthey‚Äôre not complicated at all. They require only your decision to look for the best in yourself day after day, and moment after moment. For all of you who grew up believing that you should remember your mistakes and imperfections as a way to achieve success, these exercises represent a big change in our thinking habits. How well are those current thinking habits working for you? Are you gaining confidence every day no matter what happens to you by thinking that way? Or to paraphrase Dr. Bob Rotella from his book Your 15th Club, ‚ÄúIs your present way of thinking consistent with the level of success you‚Äôd like to have? Does it help you find out how good you could be? And do you dare to change it?‚Äù

Let‚Äôs take that dare! Start managing your memories and depositing as much ‚Äúmoney‚Äù as possible into your mental bank account.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.content:
HSS1010 is an introductory level course that allows you to explore concepts related to the determinants of health; the dimensions of wellness; basic principles of anatomy, physiology, and disease; and basic safety and reporting protocols for providing care to individuals. These concepts are directly applicable to potential post-secondary studies and future career paths in health, recreation, volunteer, and community-support settings. This course is a prerequisite for several advanced Human and Social Services courses that you may choose to enroll in during your high school studies.

In HSS1010: Health Services Foundations you will
- evaluate the determinants of good health and how these determinants affect personal wellness
- explain the basic structure and function of the human body using medical terminology
- describe safety strategies to prevent infection from blood borne pathogens in health care and recreation settings, and identify basic safety and reporting protocols for these settings
- examine the public health system, justify the importance of an active lifestyle, and identify personal opportunities to enhance wellness

You will explore the following guiding questions:
- What does it mean to be well?
- How does society define health?
- What is your personal definition of health and wellness?
- How does the human body work to achieve and maintain optimum health and wellness?
- What is the role of the individual in creating and maintaining personal health and wellness?
- What choices can you make to maximize your personal physical, mental, and spiritual health and wellness?
- What are the shared roles, rights, and responsibilities of stakeholders in maintaining safe and healthy homes, schools, and communities?

In order to succeed in this course, it is important that you understand its design and structure.

sections.heading: Course Orientation
sections.content:
This course is divided into four sections.

SECTION 1 ‚Äì DEFINING HEALTH AND WELLNESS
In this section you will explore definitions of health and wellness, and consider what it means to be healthy.

SECTION 2 ‚Äì INSIDE OUT: HOW THE BODY WORKS
In this section you will learn about the structure and function of the human body, and the basic principles of anatomy, physiology, and disease.

SECTION3 ‚Äì ROAD MAP TO HEALTH AND WELLNESS
In this section you will learn about choices you can make to ensure optimum health and wellness.

SECTION 4 ‚Äì PUBLIC HEALTH
In this section you will learn about public health systems, and the rights and responsibilities of individuals, caregivers, and other stakeholders in maintaining safe and healthy homes, schools and communities.

Each section begins with an overview page that introduces the topics, outcomes, and key questions of the section. The sections include a variety of activities, information, and assessments.

This course is designed so that you can work through it independently. If you have any questions as you work through the materials, be sure to contact your teacher.

sections.heading: Overview
sections.content:
What does it mean to be healthy? What does wellness look or feel like? Since 1948, the World Health Organization has defined health as ‚Äúa state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being‚Äù and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity. Wellness has been defined as ‚Äúan active process of becoming aware of and making choices toward a more successful existence.‚Äù

Section 1 addresses the following outcome:
- evaluate the determinants of good health in Canadian society
  - compare recognized international and national definitions of health and wellness
  - describe the twelve key determinants of health as defined by Health Canada, providing specific examples
  - describe how the determinants of health are used for evidence- based decision-making related to health care policies

Keep these guiding questions in mind as you work through Section 1:
- What does it mean to be well?
- How does society define health?
- What is your personal definition of health and wellness?

sections.heading: Dimensions of Health and Wellness
sections.content:
One way to describe health and wellness is to refer to the dimensions of wellness. The dimensions represent different influences on your total health and well-being, including physical, psychological, social, emotional, and spiritual aspects. The dimensions are interdependent‚Äîthey are constantly interacting with each other.

PHYSICAL
Physical wellness is the ability, motivation, and confidence to move effectively and efficiently in a variety of situations; and the healthy growth, development, and care of the body.

- How much sleep do you get? Do you awake feeling refreshed?
- How much physical activity do you get?
- How well-balanced is your nutrition?
- How is your general health?
- Do you avoid or minimize dangerous or risky behaviours?
- Do you regularly visit a doctor?
- How well do you manage stress?

INTELLECTUAL
Intellectual wellness is the development and the critical and creative use of the mind to its fullest potential.

- Are you interested in learning new things?
- Do you enjoy creative and stimulating mental activities?
- Are you able to think critically and solve problems effectively?
- Do you have the skills to use technology and information sources wisely?

SOCIAL
Social wellness is the ability to develop and maintain relationships and to interact positively with others.

- Do you have supportive, healthy relationships?
- Do you communicate effectively with others?
- Do you feel you belong to a group or community?
- Do you respect the diversity of others?

OCCUPATIONAL
Occupational wellness is the satisfaction and enrichment you gain from your work, school, or daily activities.

- Do you feel satisfied with your work or school experience?
- Do you feel you are using your skills and abilities?
- Do you feel challenged and motivated?

SPIRITUAL
Spiritual wellness is an understanding of one‚Äôs own values and beliefs leading to a sense of meaning or purpose and a relationship to the global community.

Do you generally feel happy and ‚Äúat peace‚Äù with your life? Do you have strong beliefs and values? Do you respect the values and beliefs of others? Do you believe your life has direction and meaning? Is there a direct relationship between your values and your daily actions?

EMOTIONAL
Emotional wellness is acknowledging, understanding, and expressing thoughts and feelings in a constructive manner.

Do you have people who you can ask for support when you need it? How much time do you spend in self-improvement and self-exploration? How self-aware are you? How well do you handle positive or negative emotions?

While there are many different versions of a ‚ÄúWellness Wheel‚Äù, all of them provide a visual representation of the concept that wellness demonstrates the need for ‚Äúbalanced‚Äù or ‚Äúwell-rounded‚Äù lives. To achieve and maintain harmony and balance in our lives, we must pay attention to all the dimensions of wellness.

sections.heading: What Determines Health?
sections.content:
According to Health Canada, wellness means making positive choices that enhance your physical, mental, and spiritual health. At every stage of life, health is determined by complex interactions between social and economic factors, the physical environment, and individual behaviour. The Public Health Agency of Canada identifies twelve key determinants of health.

Learn about them by viewing the YouTube video,

‚ÄúDeterminants of Health‚Äù by SolveSocialProblems
at   [https://goo.gl/mBx0qj

The](https://goo.gl/mBx0qj

The) determinants of health are ranked by the Public Health Agency of Canada as most influential to least influential, in the following order.

KEY DETERMINANT ‚Äì 1.  Income and Social Status

Health and wellness improve at each step up the income and social ladder. High income determines living conditions such as safe housing and ability to buy sufficient good food. The healthiest populations are those in societies which are prosperous and have an equitable distribution of wealth.

KEY DETERMINANT ‚Äì 2. Social Support Networks

When someone has a strong support network of family, friends, and community, they will generally have better health. A social support network can enable someone to solve problems and deal with adversity more effectively. The caring and respect that occurs in social relationships, and the resulting sense of satisfaction and well-being, seem to act as a buffer against health problems.

KEY DETERMINANT ‚Äì 3. Education and Literacy

Higher levels of education and literacy are associated with better health. Health status improves with each level of education. Education increases opportunities for job and income security, and provides people with a sense of control over their lives.

KEY DETERMINANT ‚Äì 4. Employment and Working Conditions

Unemployment, underemployment, and stressful or unsafe work are associated with poorer health. People who have more control over their working conditions and who are supported in the workplace have better health.

KEY DETERMINANT ‚Äì 5. Social Environments

Supportive social environments have a positive impact on health. The values and norms of society affect health and well-being. The social environment includes the ways society interacts, supports, and values individuals.

KEY DETERMINANT ‚Äì 6. Physical Environments

The physical environment includes safe water and air, healthy workplaces, safe houses, communities and roads. All of these factors contribute to good health. Natural and built environments can influence physical activity, exposure to hazards, and access to resources.

KEY DETERMINANT ‚Äì 7. Personal Health Practices and Coping Skills

Personal health practices and coping skills are related to health and wellness. They include behaviours such as diet, physical activity, and the use of alcohol, tobacco, and drugs. Coping skills also influence how people deal with stress and challenges.

KEY DETERMINANT ‚Äì 8. Healthy Child Development

The early years of life are important for health throughout the lifespan. Experiences and exposures during pregnancy and early childhood influence physical health, mental health, and coping skills.

KEY DETERMINANT ‚Äì 9. Biology and Genetic Endowment

Biology and genetic endowment influence health. Some people are more at risk for certain diseases because of inherited characteristics. However, genetics interact with social and environmental factors.

KEY DETERMINANT ‚Äì 10. Health Services

Health services include prevention and treatment services. Access to health services can influence health outcomes, but factors outside the health care system also have a significant impact on health.

KEY DETERMINANT ‚Äì 11. Gender

Gender refers to the roles, behaviours, activities, and attributes that society considers appropriate for men and women. Gender affects health risks, access to resources, and experiences within society.

KEY DETERMINANT ‚Äì 12. Culture

Culture refers to values, beliefs, and traditions. Culture can influence health practices and access to health services. In some cases, culture can provide protective factors; in other cases, it can contribute to health risks.

sections.heading: Determinants and Public Policy
sections.content:
The Public Health Agency of Canada and the World Health Organization have concluded that there is a direct correlation between the determinants of health and the health of individuals in a population.

Canada has adopted a ‚Äúpopulation health approach‚Äù to improving health care issues. A population health approach is based on the belief that factors outside the health care system significantly affect health. Canada‚Äôs public health system seeks to address these factors to improve health outcomes.

The determinants of health are used for evidence-based decision-making related to health care policies.
